I.  THE WOMEN’S FINANCING MARKETPLACE 
 
1.  The REG: Technical Assistance for the Women’s Financing Marketplace, approved in 
November  2020,  will  facilitate  and  broaden  access  to  finance  for  women  and  women's 
businesses and communicate ADB’s efforts in this area to encourage more lending to this 
sector and also generate new business for ADB.1 Many financial institutions (FIs) in ADB’s 
developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  have  not  targeted  women  borrowers  and  do  not 
recognize the untapped commercial potential.2 They do not provide suitable and affordable 
products for this clientele or lack the awareness of the barriers women or women’s businesses 
encounter when trying to access financial services. The impacts of the coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19) pandemic have also reinforced the importance of a digital economy to change 
business models into digital business models and to integrate digital channels into how financial 
service providers or businesses engage with customers. Many women’s businesses have also 
adversely been impacted by COVID-19. A survey on the impact of COVID-19 on women’s 
businesses in Papua New Guinea (PNG) has for example found that 40.9% of smaller or semi-
formal businesses have reported a temporary halt in operations. 3 
 
2.  During  this  period  and  then  post-COVID-19  and  operating  under  the  “new  normal” 
environment, a dedicated online platform can help support FIs and their existing and potential 
women borrowers. The Women’s Financing Marketplace (the Marketplace) will, therefore, be 
innovative in its work and take a digital approach for interaction and engagement as it will, 
among others, engage also through social media channels to build a subscriber and follower list 
and  facilitate the  engagement  of  an  online  community through  linkages  and  resources  on 
content relevant for the FIs and their female borrowers. The Marketplace will: (i) aggregate and 
disseminate products on gender financing within ADB and to the broader external audience;  
(ii) support the identification of cutting-edge technologies to digitize business models, such as 
alternative credit scoring models4,and delivery channels, which are expected to be piloted in one 
or two countries (PNG has been identified as the first), (iii) build capacity for FIs to promote 
gender-responsive financial service delivery and women’s businesses to improve viability, as 
needed, through a range of digital toolkits, webinars and online support, (iv) establish linkages 
to other programs and initiatives on enabling access to finance for women, internal and external 
to ADB5; and (v) create a community platform. The design, set-up, and maintenance of the 
Marketplace will be supported through the technical assistance (TA), Subproject 1. 
 
3.  The  transaction  technical  assistance  cluster  (TA  cluster)  is  envisaged  to  have  4 
subprojects:  (i)  Design,  Set  up  and  Maintenance  of  the  Marketplace,  (ii)  Innovation  and 
Technologies, (iii) Capacity Building, and (iv) Expansion of the Marketplace. 
   
 
1  Women’s business in this context means micro-, small- and medium-sized women-owned or women-managed 
businesses. 
2  Financial institutions in this context are banks and non-bank financial institutions including microfinance institutions, 
housing finance, and insurance companies, for instance. 
3  CIBE 2020. COVID-19’s Arrival in PNG: Impacts on women-owned and operated MSMEs. July 2020. Port 
Moresby. 
4  A gender-responsive credit scoring model would consider also women specific data or behavior for the algorithms. 
5  For example, PSFI’s Microfinance Risk Participation and Guarantee Program or ADB Ventures and SDCC’s 
Gender and Development initiatives or TechforImpact.

2 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
 
A.  Overall Progress of the Technical Assistance Cluster 
 
4.  This  is  the  first  subproject  under  the  REG:  Technical  Assistance  for  the  Women’s 
Financing Marketplace. 
 
B.  Subproject Scope  
 
5.  The TA cluster has the following overall outcome: sustainable financial inclusion for 
women and women’s businesses increased. Subproject 1 will contribute to this through the 
design, set-up, and maintenance of the Marketplace.  
 
C.  Subproject Outputs and Activities  
 
6.  Output 1: Finalized Design and Set up of the Marketplace. To achieve the objective 
of an online interactive platform that is frequently used, requires a good understanding of the 
emerging issues in gender-responsive financing, innovative technologies to digitize gender- 
responsive  financial  services  delivery  or  women’s  businesses  operating  models  and 
identification of other support needs of the target group (foremost FIs and women’s businesses). 
This entails moving to a more engaging approach which creates interaction between ADB and 
the target audience in DMCs. During and post COVID-19, it will also require a digital approach 
to interaction and engagement – including using social media channels such as LinkedIn, 
Facebook or Twitter, for capacity building and support for cutting-edge technology. Constant 
monitoring of data on website traffic, preferences, feedback, trends and audience appetite and 
interests will help to further develop the platform. It is envisaged that the establishment of the 
Marketplace will happen in stages, whereby the first stage will be to set-up a landing page at 
ADB.org with the support of the Department of Communications (DOC).6 After a review at the 
end of year one, it will be decided together with DOC how additional necessary features can be 
further supported by ADB.org or whether other solutions should be evaluated.  
 
7.  As a first step, a mapping of existing gender finance initiatives, data analytics and survey 
with PSFI’s clients will be conducted. Together with a digital agency, the look and feel of the 
website and interaction with clients/people through social media channels (Facebook, LinkedIn, 
Twitter, etc.) and subscribers to the website (newsletter, updates, specific digital services), the 
website will be designed taking into consideration such feedback. Second, partnerships with 
public and private sector stakeholders and linkages with other initiatives will be facilitated. Third, 
ADB’s content on gender-based financing will be identified and transformed into a user friendly, 
digital content for the website. 
 
8.  Output 2: Maintenance of the Marketplace. A key challenge will be to create sufficient 
quality content that the audience would find interesting and with which they are likely to engage. 
In addition, it will be important to publicize and disseminate the platform’s content and activities. 
This will be achieved through a range of activities, such as website updates, newsletters and 
other social media cross-promotions and institutional partnerships. To support ADB with these 
activities, resources will be contracted. During this time, the subscriber base and social media 
contacts will be built-up to start interaction to “feel the pulse” of the community and obtain early 
 
6  DOC’s support will be through their involvement in the design phase of the website as well as updating of content. 
Additional resources have been allocated in the budget to complement DOC.

3 
feedback. 
 
9.  Output  3:  Review.  To  further  shape  and  expand  the  website  with  demand  driven 
features a review will take place at the end of year one. This will be used to continue with the 
design  sprint  exercise  (website  prototype,  live  proof  of  concept  to  captive  audience),  the 
technology operating model,7 and the business case8 to be able to decide what interactive 
features the website should have and discuss how ADB.org can support these and whether 
there is a need to set up an independent website or remain within ADB.org. These decisions will 
be taken in coordination with PSOD, DOC and ITD. During the year, feedback will be collected 
through interaction with subscribers and social media contacts, as well as surveys with partner 
financial institutions and research (carried out during the design sprint exercise). 
 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
 
10.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $600,000, of which $200,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by TASF – Donor Contribution, and $400,000 by TASF – Income Transfer. The 
funds will cover website development, IT infrastructure (as necessary), preparation, layout and 
design of content material, conference-related (seminar) expenses, remuneration, travel, and 
per diem for international/national consultants, and miscellaneous expenses.

11.  ADB  will  administer  Subproject  1  and  its  Private  Sector  Operations  Department, 
Financial Institutions Division, will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants in collaboration 
with Department of Communication.

Procurement  Policy  (2017,  as  amended  from  time  to  time)  and  the  associated  project

used, as appropriate. 
 
13.   Social media and websites. The TA cluster will initially use ADB-supported website 
and social media channels that are maintained by DOC, and follow the ADB Guidelines on
